linkTarget.anchoringText: The fields of Casabe Alliance are located in the mid-Magdalena River valley in Colombia, South America. Peñas Blancas field is about 10 km from Casabe Sur field and 15 km from Casabe field, as shown in Fig. 1.

image-wrap.label: Figure 1
image-wrap.caption: Peñas Blancas, Casabe, and Casabe Sur fields.

formatted-caption.caption-text: Peñas Blancas, Casabe, and Casabe Sur fields.

linkTarget.anchoringText: According to the FRDP production forecasts, Peñas Blancas field would produce a peak of 3,980 BOPD, with a gas-oil ratio (GOR) of 100 scf/bbl and a total liquid peak production of 10,116 B/D. (Fig. 2.

image-wrap.label: Figure 2
image-wrap.caption: Production forecast of Peñas Blancas field.

formatted-caption.caption-text: Production forecast of Peñas Blancas field.

linkTarget.anchoringText: Elevation profile as shown in Fig. 3

image-wrap.label: Figure 3
image-wrap.caption: Elevation profile from Peñas Blancas to Casabe Sur station.

formatted-caption.caption-text: Elevation profile from Peñas Blancas to Casabe Sur station.

linkTarget.anchoringText: This type of pump is shown in Fig. 4.

Once the pump information was assessed, and considering some other facts as solid production (due to the waterflooding) and an expected low gas production, the PCP pump (shown in Fig. 5) was selected for the Peñas Blancas multiphase pumping station.

PCPs belong to the family of positive displacement pumps. The key components are a rotating rotor within a static stator. As the rotor turns within the stator, it forms cavities between the stator and the eccentrically rotating rotor. These cavities progress continuously in rotating motion along an axial direction (see Fig. 6.

image-wrap.label: Figure 6
image-wrap.caption: PCP and incremental discharge pressure per stage.

formatted-caption.caption-text: PCP and incremental discharge pressure per stage.

linkTarget.anchoringText: As part of the pump design, the sealing between rotor and stator is not complete; the volumetric losses are controlled by the manufacturer using the right interference fit between rotor and stator. The actual flow rate of a PCP is then influenced by its internal slippage, which is a function of the differential pressure (see Fig. 7) and the interference fit determined by rotor (outside diameter), stator (inside diameter), viscosity of the fluid, turning speed, stator swelling, and medium temperature.

Four different types of elastomers were tested with Peñas Blancas fluid (see Fig. 8), the elastomers were the following polymers: 286, 288 (new technology), 289 (new technology), and the 320; the results demonstrate the ability of elastomers 286 –289 maintain stability over the projection period studied. Additionally, the elastomer 286 had a stable behavior with a minimum weight gain of 1.67% and the elastomer 320 stands out by its low hardness variation of 2.7%.

image-wrap.label: Figure 8
image-wrap.caption: Elastomer test for Peñas Blancas multiphase pumps.

formatted-caption.caption-text: Elastomer test for Peñas Blancas multiphase pumps.

linkTarget.anchoringText: To control the pump suction pressure, as shown in Fig. 9, a set pressure between 30 and 50 psi is fixed and the speed frequency variator (voltage frequency drive, VFD) will be varied to maintain that pressure.

image-wrap.label: Figure 9
image-wrap.caption: Control system for the multiphase pumps. (***)

formatted-caption.caption-text: Control system for the multiphase pumps. (***)

linkTarget.anchoringText: Chemical injection. Another way to improve the fluid transportation and reduce the high discharge pressure of the multiphase pumps is to add a drag reducing agent (DRA) in the system. A DRA is an “anti-turbulent polymer chemical that, when injected into a pipeline (where the fluid is turbulent) can modify the flow regime by reducing the frictional pressure drop along the pipeline length or serve as a pipeline booster” (Qflo 2014). This solution should be tested in the Peñas Blancas multiphase system, but it must be injected into the discharge pump side, as shown in Fig. 10.

image-wrap.label: Figure 10
image-wrap.caption: Chemical injection point for reducing discharge pressure (Qflo 2014]

formatted-caption.caption-text: Chemical injection point for reducing discharge pressure (Qflo 2014]

linkTarget.anchoringText: The selected multiphase meter includes the following components (Fig. 11):

image-wrap.label: Figure 11
image-wrap.caption: Multiphase meter for Peñas Blancas field.

formatted-caption.caption-text: Multiphase meter for Peñas Blancas field.

linkTarget.anchoringText: The test was performed with a well testing unit for the separation of fluids. The oil and water were measured in storage tanks, and the gas was measured with an orifice plate flow meter (Fig. 12).
Orifice meter inspection according to report AGA3, part 2 (including orifice plates, plates port, flow conditioner, pipelines) (Fig. 13)

The results of the test where satisfactory for the multiphase meter. Fig. 15 compares the results for liquid rate. The first axis shows that the liquid rate was between 300 BFPD and 1225 BFPD. The second axis shows the relative error, ε, where ε (Multiphase meter – Reference) / Reference, with the upper and lower limits required. All the points of the case were accepted.
The range of the water cut measured was between 3% and 12%. Even though not all the points were inside the technical requirements, 87% of the points fulfilled the requirements (Fig. 16).

The range of the gas rate was between 40,000 scfd and 195,000 scfd. Gas measurement with the orifice plate of the testing unit involves some uncertainty that could be reflected in the results shown in Fig. 17.
